{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3661641,"name":"Michael Jansen","username":"mjansen4857","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjansen4857/{size}/201972_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T20:52:00.429Z","cooked":"

Just received our team’s SystemCore alpha testing unit, and I love electronics teardowns so I had to take a look inside and share pictures for everyone here.

First of all, roboRIO for scale.

image1920×1440 184 KB

Close-up of the front of the device. The front enclosure is 3D-printed (obviously temporary for these early devices). I believe it is printed out of some form of nylon via SLS or MJF printing. Someone more familiar can correct me on that.

image1920×1440 223 KB

image1920×1440 313 KB

Rear of the device showing the M.2 slot for the Hailo accelerator, currently also 3D printed, but this looks to be FDM.

image1920×1440 137 KB

image1920×1440 144 KB

The rear of the enclosure is anodized aluminum, same as Limelight 3G/A and 4. It acts as a heatsink for the compute module SoC and Hailo module.

image1920×1440 119 KB

Inside of the device. The PCB is covered with a conformal coating to protect against debris. The compute module is the 4GB RAM configuration.

image1920×1440 242 KB

PCB behind the smart IO connectors.

image1920×1440 244 KB

PCB behind the power input/motion core connector.

image1920×1440 200 KB

PCB behind some of the CAN connectors. Most of these are blocked by the compute module (not brave enough to disconnect anything from the board this early).

image1920×1440 164 KB

PCB behind the USB/I2C connectors.

image1920×1440 188 KB

Front of the PCB.

image1920×1440 220 KB

Close-up of the power stage.

image1920×1440 239 KB

Close-up to the right of the display board. Notably has an unused mezzanine connector labelled “Aux” above the antenna wire. Not sure if this is meant for anything specific, or left over from previous designs. Also has a connector for an RTC battery.

image1920×1440 165 KB

The display board. Also has status LEDs and WiFi antenna.

image1920×1440 208 KB

wow! I love this!

Looks to have an individual CAN transciever chip for each CANbus, as I thought earlier. I’ll take a closer look and come back with my thoughts soon

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":73,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T21:07:38.634Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":1103,"readers_count":1102,"score":370.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503555,"topic_slug":"systemcore-teardown-pictures","display_username":"Matthew K","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":9}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55172,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"barn2robotics alumni"},"post_url":"/t/systemcore-teardown-pictures/503555/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":9}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":9,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3661665,"name":"","username":"TyJac42","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tyjac42/{size}/230279_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T21:22:20.576Z","cooked":"

Overall it looks great I am super excited for this.

My only question based on this design is how they manage the heat. The RPi 5 lacks heatsinking and I know from experience they can get pretty hot running vision detection pipelines in closed cases.

I am interested to hear about the temps from alpha teams and whether they underclock the Pis to manage heat or something along those lines.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":73,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T21:22:20.576Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":1093,"readers_count":1092,"score":268.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503555,"topic_slug":"systemcore-teardown-pictures","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53544,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming, CAD"},"post_url":"/t/systemcore-teardown-pictures/503555/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3661671,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T21:27:03.791Z","cooked":"
TyJac42:

My only question based on this design is how they manage the heat. The RPi 5 lacks heatsinking and I know from experience they can get pretty hot running vision detection pipelines in closed cases.

As shown, the entire bottom case is anodized aluminum that is thermally coupled to the lid of the CM5 SoC. So it’s a big passive heatsink.

Oh, oops. I just glazed over that. I assumed it was all nylon from the first picture. That should serve as a decent heatsink.

Maybe I missed it when the specs were posted, but I’m curious as all get out why there is a WIFi/BT antenna connected via u.fl connector on the CM5?

The compute module is the 4GB RAM configuration.

Excited to have more than 512 mb of memory.

The screen is driven off of a RP2350.

There’s a handy utility built into the OS that flashes said RP2350 on boot with a uf2 also in the OS.

There’s a project that will run Doom on a 2350 and similar LCD screen

The LINK port enables cross-platform connectivity over USB-C. This is an alternative interface to the Ethernet and Wi-Fi interfaces. If the LINK port is attached to a device atboot time, Systemcore enters flash mode for recovery OS updates

I really like the DIO being 24 V tolerant, as well as the section about debris mitigation!

I wonder if the 5GHz access point mode will work for FRC at-home testing? We’ve certainly gotten in situations where we didn’t plan ahead and were stuck struggling with 2.4 on the VH-109.
